journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Novel optimization method to estimate the geometrical properties of a multiaxial 3D woven preform

article-meta.aff: ENSAIT, University of Lille Nord de France, Roubaix, France

author-notes.corresp: Ahmad Rashed Labanieh, ENSAIT, University of Lille Nord de France, 2 allée Louise et Victor Champier BP 30329 59056 Roubaix, France. Email: ahmad.labanieh@ensait.fr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This article describes a contribution to the development of a numerical model for the geometrical description of multiaxial 3D woven preforms, at the scale of a unit cell. A novel approach enabling computation of preforms cross-section dimensions depending on the manufacturing and weaving parameters has been developed. The aims of this model are first to establish the relationships between geometrical parameters to construct a representative volume element of the structure, which can be used for finite element modeling, and second to optimize the description of the structure taking into account the specificities of these woven architectures. With this geometrical tool, the influence of the waviness of the binder tows, of the choice of the tows cross section on the fiber volume fraction is illustrated and discussed. Several numerical configurations of multiaxial 3D woven preforms are computed and compared. Finally to show the advantages of this woven architecture, the numerical model is used to compare the geometrical properties of multiaxial 3D woven preforms with those of other equivalent 3D preform configurations like 3D woven interlock preform or laminate preform.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Laminated composite materials have been used widely for structural applications because of their high specific stiffness and strength, high specific energy absorption, and excellent fatigue performance.1,2 However, the incapability to have fibers in the through-the-thickness direction of the laminate greatly reduces the damage tolerance, impact resistance and delamination resistance, which can result in disastrous failures.2–4 To address this, a stitching technology5 has been developed, involving reinforcement of the dry laminate preform by insertion of fibers in the form of stitches in the through-thickness direction. This approach improves the modeI delamination toughness, with its effectiveness depending on the stitching parameters and on the type of fiber used for the stitch material. It can also increase the strength after impact by more than 80%.6 However, the in-plane properties of the stitched preforms are influenced by local fiber displacement and the formation of resin pockets in the cured laminate, due to the stitching procedure.7 It has been shown that these in-plane properties could be reduced by as much as 20%8 compared to a laminated preform. On the other hand, 3D weaving technology has also been developed to produce preforms containing through-thickness fiber reinforcement. These woven preforms also exhibit improved delamination resistance and fracture toughness.9–11 However, the 3D woven preforms have just two sets of the in-plane fibers, the warp and the weft threads, resulting in reduction of their in-plane off-axis tensile properties and their shear in-plane resistance. Therefore, multiaxial 3D woven preform technology12 has been developed to produce fiber-reinforced preforms that combine out-of-plane 3D properties produced by weaving the through-thickness fiber reinforcement and in-plane properties resulting from the presence of in-plane bias fibers.

To characterize and describe these textile preform architectures several models, at the scale of a representative volume element (RVE), have been developed.13–15 Those numerical models are classified in geometrical and mechanical models. The first family represents these architectures numerically and quantifies geometrical parameters (especially the fiber volume fraction) in function of the architecture choice (orientation and number of yarns in each direction for example). The second family, using early a geometrical model for the description of the RVE geometry, computes mechanical properties, by finite element or analytical approaches. These computations can analyze the influence of the preform parameters (for example the effect of yarns in the thickness) on the stiffness and strength of the RVE.

Associated with the development of a multiaxial 3D woven technology to produce samples,16 the prediction of the characteristics of RVE by development of numerical models is an essential step. The study presented in this article is related to this subject, and particularly based on the model developed by Buchanan et al.17 for the prediction of geometrical properties for multiaxial 3D woven preform. In this article, and more generally for all the geometrical models at the scale of the RVE, hypothesis concerning the cross section of the yarns (choice of the geometry of the cross section and values associated), and their influence on the fiber volume fraction are introduced and defined. In Buchanan’s model, a constant aspect ratio of the tow cross section is supposed to be achieved. However, this assumption can conduce, for specific multiaxial 3D woven architecture, to have some penetrations between yarns in the RVE model. Consequently in this article, an optimization approach is first proposed in order to compute the cross-section dimensions of the tows in the preform in function of manufacturing and weaving parameters. From this optimization, numerical configurations of multiaxial 3D woven can be proposed with different fiber volume fractions. In these configurations several methods described in the Ansar et al.13 and Buchanan et al.17,18 to estimate the overall fiber volume fraction, are used and discussed. In the description of the unit cell, the influence of the waviness especially for binder tows is analyzed for its effect on the global thickness of the RVE (and consequently on the global volume). These developments concerning multiaxial 3D woven preforms, is described in the second section of this article; associated with their parameters, also the geometrical model including hypothesis and the optimization loop for the cross section is presented. Finally, results obtained after analyzing several configurations of multiaxial 3D woven preforms are presented in the later four. In addition, in the last part of this section, the geometrical model is applied to an equivalent laminate and an equivalent 3D orthogonal woven preforms. Then the geometrical properties are computed and compared with those of multiaxial 3D woven preforms in order to quantify the influence of the biases tows on geometrical properties.

sec.title: Development of a geometrical model for multiaxial 3D woven preform
General description of multiaxial 3D woven preform
sec.p:
Due to the additional sets of in-plane fibers with specific angles, the multiaxial 3D woven preform exhibit better in-plane shear resistance compared to 3D woven interlock architecture.12 The technology used to produce these preforms differs from ‘traditional’ 3D weaving technologies in the transversal movement of the bias tows, with respect to the longitudinal warp feeding direction. This movement should be repeated for all weaving cycles to form small accurate spaces to insert the binder tows. This leads to several modifications of the other weaving operations. Several articles and patents have been published recently in order to develop the multiaxial 3D weaving technology as reported in various literatures.2,11,12,19–25 These technologies enables to product many architectures of multiaxial 3D woven preforms by the definition of specific manufacturing parameters (such as the title of the constitutive tows) or weaving parameters (such as the number of layers and the density of tows in the preform), which have an influence on the characteristics of preform and consequently on the mechanical properties of multiaxial 3D woven preforms. Associated with these technologies the development of geometrical models is necessary for several reasons. First to visualize the unit cell in terms of parameters associated, second to have a geometry which can be used to generate meshes for finite element analysis at the scale of the RVE, and third to analyze the influence of manufacturing and weaving parameters on the preform which characterizes the geometry of the preform. These geometrical models are built from geometrical relationships between different parameters which are detailed in Table 1 and also in Figure 1. An example of the constitution of a multiaxial 3D woven preforms is given Figure 2. This preform is constituted of four distinct tow sets with different orientations. The first set is composed of the warp tows that are oriented along the longitudinal direction of the preform (axis 0° in Figure 2). The second set is constituted of the bias tows positioned in the plane of the preform but oriented in inclined directions with respect to the longitudinal direction of the preform. Half of these tows is inclined at +45° to the warp direction (axis 45° in Figure 2) and respectively at −45° (axis −45° in Figure 2) for the second half. The third set is composed of the weft tows, in the plane of the preform and perpendicular to the warp direction (axis 90° in Figure 2). The last set concerns the through-thickness threads, denoted binder, in order to link the different in-plane layers. In consequence, the preform has five axes, associated with the axes of the component threads, as illustrated in Figure 2. Figure 1.
Representation of a unit cell of a multiaxial 3D woven preform: (a) top view for the analyzed structure; (b) top view for the unit cell; (c) front view for the unit cell; (d) side view for the unit cell.
Figure 2.
Representation of a multiaxial 3D woven preforms.
Table 1.
The specified manufacturing, weaving and geometric parameters characterizing the multiaxial 3D woven preforms
Manufacture-specified parameters:
μs, μf,μb, μ45 Tex Linear density of the stiffer, filler, binder and bias(oriented at ±45°) tows
ρ g/cm3 Density of the stiffer, filler, binder and bias tows
Pf Packing factor representing the arrangement of the filament within the tow13 (Pf = 0.7854 rectangular packing arrayor Pf = 0.9069 for hexagonal packing array)
Weaver-specified parameters:
nsuc Number of stiffers along the weft direction in the unit cell
nfuc Number of fillers along the warp direction in the unit cell
nbuc Number of binders along the weft direction in the unit cell
n45uc Number of bias tows(oriented at ±45°) along the weft direction in the unit cell
λs, λf, λ±45 tows/cm Number of stiffers, filler and binder per unit length perpendicular to tow direction
λbs tows/cm Number of repeated units of the binder tows per unit length, along the stiffer direction
λbf tows/cm Number of binders per unit length, along the filler direction
ns, nf, n+45, n−45 Number of stiffers, fillers and bias layers in the unit cell.
geometrical parameters:
ls, lf, lb, l45, l−45 mm Width of the stiffer, filler, binder and bias tows
hs, hf, hb, h45, h−45 mm Thickness of the stiffer, filler, binder and bias tows
ARs, ARf, AR45, ARb Aspect ratio of the large of the tow to its thickness
Ls, Lf, L45, L−45 mm Total length of the stiffer, filler, binder and bias tows in the unit cell
H mm Thickness of the unit cell
Lb mm Total length of the vertical and horizontal components of the binder tow in the unit cell
Lx, Ly mm Length of unit cell in the X and Y directions
Vs, Vf, Vb, V45, V−45 mm3 Total volume of stiffer, filler, binder and bias tows
Vfs, Vff, Vfb, Vf45, Vf−45 Volume fraction of stiffer, filler, binder and bias tows
Vuc mm3 Volume of the unit cell
Auc mm2 Area of unit cell in the XY plane
Muc g Masse of the fiber in the unit cell
Suc g/mm2 Areal density of unit cell
FVF % Overall fiber volume fraction in the unit cell
s
: stiffer tow; f: filler tow; b: binder tow; 45: biases tows (oriented at ±45°).

sec.title: Hypothesis of the Model
sec.p:
Numerical geometrical models have been developed by Ansar et al.13 and Buchanan et al.17 for 3D orthogonal woven and multiaxial 3D woven preform.18 In Buchanan’s model,18 the cross-sectional shapes of all the tows were considered elliptic (Figure 3) with values of the aspect ratio of the cross section, denoted by AR (defined by the ratio of width to its thickness, l/h) equal to 11, for all constitutive tows, excepting for binder tow which was considered equal to 4. This value has been considered constant for all manufacturing and weaving parameters. A lot of geometrical parameters, which characterize the geometry of the multiaxial 3D woven preform, depend essentially of the hypothesis concerning the tow cross section. For the preform architectures described in this study, the fixed values of the aspect ratio (AR), proposed by Buchanan et al.18 to calculate the cross section of the constitutive tows, do not allow to obtain a RVE model due to the penetration of tows. Therefore, a novel optimization for geometrical model, to compute the cross-section dimensions of tows in function of the manufacturing and weaving parameters, has been proposed instead of a fixed aspect ratio for all tows. The other assumptions considered in our model at the scale of the tows are based on classical hypothesis:13,17,18 the tows are considered to remain straight inside the unit cell (Figures 1 and 2). The cross-section shape was first considered as elliptic, for the four groups of tows (stiffer, filler, biases and binder). This cross section could be characterized by its dimensions, and its aspect ratio AR = l/h. The cross section of tows does not change along the tow length. Figure 3.
The elliptic cross section.

Due to the tension applied on the binder tow during weaving process, filler tows will be crimped; the crown part of the binder tows (Figure 4) will be in the same plane of the filler tows, whereas the trajectory of tows are considered straight in the structure (first hypothesis) in this proposed model to simplify the RVE model. As a result, the filler’s undulation was not taken into account. Hence, at the scale of the unit cell, this simplification leads the proposal of two configurations illustrated in Figure 4, dissociated by the computation of the total thickness of the RVE. In the first case, denoted crowned configuration, (Figure 4(a)), the crown part of the binder will be taken into consideration, and the thickness of the RVE is noted as Hc. In the second case (Figure 4(b)), denoted uncrowned configuration, the tension applied on the binder tows is supposed to result in the crimping of the in-plane tows that compresses the structure. To avoid crimping of the filler tow in the model, the crown part of the binder tow has not been considered. This assumption is used by Buchanan et al.18 to compute the thickness of the RVE which is noted as Huc. These hypotheses on the definition of the thickness have been studied in the geometric model developed by Rao et al.14 in case of 3D orthogonal woven composite. They have a significant influence on the volume of the RVE computation, and the fiber volume fraction. Consequently, when these geometric models are used to determine mechanical characteristics, the complementary thickness (respectively volume) is filled by an additional quantity of resin. Figure 4.
Definition of the thickness of the RVE: (a) crowned configuration; (b) uncrowned configuration.
RVE: representative volume element.

sec.title: Calculation of the cross-section dimension of the tow
sec.p:
Compared to the works presented in the literature, and before the calculation of the classically geometric parameters, our geometrical model has a first step dedicated to the computation of the dimension of tows cross section. The objective of this step, illustrated by a flow chart presented in Figure 5, is to compute, for each set of tows, the cross-section dimensions (l,h). Figures 1 and 6 describe different views of the unit cell associated with the equations detailed in this section. At the beginning, aspect ratios of tows must be initialized. For stiffer, filler and biases tows, AR = 11 (from works of Buchanan). Figure 5.
Flow chart for the optimization method concerning the dimension of the cross sections of different tows.
Figure 6.
A top view for the unit cell.
From initials values, the dimensions (li,hi) of the tows, are computed (equation (1)) (1)hi=4μi10-3πPfρili=4μi10-3πPfρiARiARi=lihi(i=s,f,45)
The optimization procedure is based, firstly, on the measure of the unit cell length along the stiffer tow (along x, Figure 6) as detailed in the following equation. (2)Lx=10.nfucλf=10λbs
The dimensions of the cross section for the binder tow are obtained by equation (3) illustrated in Figure 6 (3)l45cos(45)+lb+nfuc2lf+hb=10λbshb=4μb10-3πPfρblb

Then, the geometric in-plane condition (equation (4)) expresses that the bias and the filler tows could be positioned along this dimension in function of their characteristics (li,hi) computed from the initial values of aspect ratio AR = 11 (4)nfuclf+2hb≤10λbs
If this condition is not satisfied, dimensions of binder and filler tow are recalculated (equation (5)) (5)lb=5λbs-l45cos(45) lf=(10λbs-2hb)/nfuchi=4μi10-3πPfρili(i=b,f)

The same approach is applied along the second in-plane dimension of the unit cell (along y, Figure 6) for the stiffer tow. It was supposed that the two in-plane unit cell lengths along the stiffer tow and along filler tow (equation (6)) are equal to satisfy the orientation of the biases tows at ±45° to the stiffer direction. Then, through the condition expressed (equation (7)) the stiffer tows cross-section dimensions will be verified (6)Ly=10.nsucλs=10λbf=Lx (7)nsucls+lb≤10λbf
If this condition is not satisfied, dimensions of stiffer are recalculated. (8)ls=(10λbf-lb)/nsuchs=4μs10-3πPfρsls

sec.title: Computation of the unit cell geometrical parameters
sec.p: After the definition of dimensions of all tows in the unit cell, it is possible to compute, in the second step, all geometrical parameters characterizing the RVE.

For the computation of the unit cell thickness, as defined previously (Figure 4), two configurations, crowned (thickness denoted as Hc) or uncrowned (thickness denoted as Huc) have been envisaged (9)Hc=nshs+nfhf+n+45h+45+n-45h-45+2hbHuc=nshs+nfhf+n+45h+45+n-45h-45
Associated with the thickness, the unit cell volume can be deduced as (10)Vuc=Lx.Ly.H with H respectively equal to Hc or Huc for crowned or uncrowned configuration.
The total length of each set of tows in the unit cell can be computed (11)Ls=10.nfucλf.nsuc.ns Lf=10.nsucλs.nfuc.nfL45=[10.nfucλfcos(45)]n45uc.n45Lb=[10.nfucλf+2(Hc-2.hb)].nbucorLb=2Huc.nbuc
The binder tow could be computed as expressed in equations (11) depending on the binder tow configuration (crowned or uncrowned).
The volume of each tow in the unit cell is defined by (12)Vi=π.li.hi4.Li (i=s,f,45,b)
The overall volume of the fiber in the unit cell can be calculated as (13)Vfibre=Vs+Vf+Vb+V45+V-45
The mass of the fiber in the unit cell as well the areal density can be calculated by (14)Muc=∑,i=s,f,b,45LiμiSuc=MucLx.Ly

The fiber volume fraction in the unit cell (equation (15)) is estimated in the literature by two methods. The first, noted as FVFvolume is based on the ratio in terms of volume.13 The second method, called FVFweight, is based on the ratio in terms of weight,18 from the areal density of fibers. In this formula, H is equal to Hc or Huc respectively for crowned or uncrowned configuration. (15)FVFvolume=VfibreVucFVFweight=SucρH
The specific proportion of each tow relative to the total fiber volume can be defined (16)Vfi=ViVfibre.100 (i=s,f,45,b)
The specific proportion of each tow relative to the unit cell volume is also estimated (17)Viuc=ViVuc100(i=s,f,45,b)

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In these numerical applications, carbon tows were used (ρ = 1.76 g/cm3) and the arrangement of filaments within the tow was considered to be hexagonal packing array (Pf = 0.9069). The count of the bias and stiffer tows have been chosen constant (μs = μ45 = 800 Tex). According to the technology that produces the multiaxial 3D woven preforms, also the subject of a forthcoming article, the number of the fillers, bias and binder tows in the unit length (λf = 4 tow/cm, λ+45−45 = 1 tow/cm, λbs = λbf = 1 tow/cm) have been fixed. In this section, the optimization approach presented previously will be applied first to compute the geometric parameters for several configurations of multiaxial 3D woven preform. Then, we will study the influence of some variation from initial hypothesis presented, like the choice of other cross section. Then the influences of the number of layers will be studied. In a last section, the geometrical model will be used to compare multiaxial 3D woven preforms with other 3D architectures.

sec.title: Analyses of the influence of filler and binder tows title and the stiffer density
sec.p:
With the optimization loop detailed previously, several configurations of multiaxial 3D woven preforms have been generated. In the results presented in Table 2, different values of the title for filler and binder tow (μf,μb,) and of the number of stiffer per unit length (λs) have been considered. In these examples, a square unit cell (Lx=Ly) is defined and the distance between two repeated binders along the filler direction (λbf) is equal to the distance between two repeated binder along the stiffer direction (λbs). Table 2.
Evolution of the cross-section dimension in function of the title and the linear density of stiffer
2-A2-B2-C2 2-A2-B3-C2 2-A2-B2-C1 2-A2-B3-C1 2-A1-B3-C3 2-A1-B2-C2 2-A1-B3-C2 2-A1-B2-C1 2-A1-B3-C1
μf (Tex) 396 396 396 396 800 800 800 800 800
μb (Tex) 396 396 800 800 198 396 396 800 800
λs (cm−1) 2 3 2 3 3 2 3 2 3
ARs 11 10,08 11 10,08 11 11 11 11 11
ARf 11 11 11 11 9.31 8.83 8.83 7.90 7,90
ARb 18.12 18.12 7.86 7.86 9.94 4.97 4.97 2.46 2,46

The bias tows in the structure are just restricted by the binder tow along the stiffer direction as illustrated in Figure 1(c) and (d). The aspect ratio for the stiffer tow, as it appears in Table 2, is still quasi-constant and near to the initial value because it depends greatly on its title, which is considered constant in this study unlike the aspect ratio for binder and fillers tows that can vary in large range. Some higher values reaching for two configurations, 2-A2-B2-C2 and 2-A2-B3-C2, are not realistic from physical point of view. This optimization loop shows that it is not possible to consider the aspect ratio of tows as constant for all RVE. Associated with these configurations, for a same number of layers, the geometrical properties of these architectures have been computed and presented in Table 3. Except for the binder tows, and for all architectures, the influence of the thickness (crowned or uncrowned configuration) is of the same order on the ratio of each set of fibers relatively to the total volume of fibers (Vfs,Vff,Vf45) or to volume of the unit cell (Vsuc,Vfuc,V45uc). However, these two types of thickness configuration (crowned and uncrowned) can conduce to singular differences on the overall fiber volume fraction computed, in the order of 8–9% for 3 configurations and it could reach 32% for the preforms 2-A1-B2-C1 and 2-A1-B3-C1. Rao et al.14 has shown this effect of the thickness (between crowned and uncrowned configurations) on the mechanical properties of a 3D woven composite architecture. Table 3.
The geometrical properties of the architectures

For the two estimation methods of the overall fiber volume fraction in the unit cell (FVFvolume and FVFweight), it may be noticed that for all studied preforms, the approach based on the volume (FVFvolume) always gives higher fiber volume fraction than that based on the weight (FVFweight). This difference is in relation with a packing factor. In the approach based on the volume, the volume fiber is corrected by this packing factor, which is not the case in the approach based on the weight.

From Table 3, Figure 7 represents, for each preform not only the fiber volume fractions (computed by the weight method) but also the rate of the stiffer fibers related to the filler fibers. Three preforms from this figure can be selected in terms of higher overall fiber volume fraction and a ratio between filler and stiffer tows near to 1, to have equivalent in-plane properties (configurations 2-A1-B3-C3, 2-A1-B3-C2 and 2-A1-B3-C1). Figure 7.
Fiber volume fraction and rate of the stiffer fibers related to the filler fibers for the multiaxial 3D woven preform.

sec.title: Evolution of the geometrical model
sec.p:
In this model hypothesis, we considered that tows are perfectly straight and consequently tow orientations are respected, especially the angle between the binder tow and the preform plane, denoted as alpha (α), has been considered equal to 90°. However, during the weaving process, some preform could not be compacted, and as a result the sequenced tows in the stiffer direction are lightly separated. Consequently, the angle of the binder tows can change and its length in the preform differs from those computed in the model. Representations of these variations, at the scale of the unit cell, are illustrated in Figure 8. For some configurations defined in Table 2, we report in Table 4 differences in term of binder tows length and overall fiber volume fraction of variation of these inclination. It could be concluded that inclination of the binder tow in the preform depends essentially on the filler and binder tow title (for constant biases tows title). In the uncrowned configuration the difference caused in the binder tow length is more important compared to the crowned configuration, but in both the cases the influence produced on the fiber volume fraction is less than ±0.3% that could be negligible. Figure 8.
illustration for the inclination of the binder tow in the throw thickness direction in a unit cell of the 2-A2-B3-C1 architecture: (a) α is less than 90°; (b) α is equal to 90°.
Table 4.
Influence of the inclination of the binder tow on the fiber volume fraction and on the binder tow length
2-A2-B2-C2 2-A2-B3-C2 2-A2-B2-C1 2-A2-B3-C1
μf (Tex) 396 396 396 396
μb (Tex) 396 396 800 800
λs (1/cm) 2 3 2 3
α (°) 77 77 83.8 83.8
Dif. Lb (%) −6.47 7.75 −6.47 7.75 −3.29 0.48 −3.29 0.48
Dif. FVFweight (%) −0.23 0.09 −0.19 0.07 −0.23 0.01 −0.19 0.01

The second hypothesis of the presented model is regarding the shape of the cross section, we considered the same elliptical shape for all tows. In order to study the influence of this consideration on the geometrical properties, other shapes have been assigned for the 2-A1-B3-C3 architecture, selected previously as an optimized multiaxial 3D woven preform. The following four cases of cross-section shapes configuration have been considered: Case 1: elliptic for all tows; Case 2: rectangular for all tows; Case 3: rectangular for stiffer and filler tows and elliptic for biases and binder tows. Case 4: rectangular for stiffer tows, square for filler tows and elliptic for biases and binder tows. With these hypothesis, we report in Table 5 the geometrical parameters computed by our model. Comparisons of the fiber volume fraction (computed from the weight method) have been represented in Figure 9. Compared to Case 1, studied previously, the choice of rectangular cross section for all tows (Case 2) can optimize this architecture. Figure 9.
Evolution of the fiber volume fraction in the 2-A1-B3-C3 architecture in function of the choice of the cross-section shape.
Table 5.
Influence of the cross-section shape on the geometrical properties of the 2-A1-B3-C3 architecture. Case 1: elliptic (all tows). Case 2: rectangular (all tows). Case 3: rectangular for stiffer and filler tows and elliptic for biases and binder tows. Case 4: rectangular for stiffer tows, square for filler tows and elliptic for biases and binder tows
Case 1 Case 2 Case 4 Case 4
ARs 11 11 11 11
ls (mm) 2.65 2.35 2.35 2.35
hs (mm) 0.24 0.21 0.21 0.21
ARf 9.31 11 11 1
lf (mm) 2.44 2.35 2.35 0.71
hf (mm) 0.26 0.21 0.21 0.71

sec.title: Influence of the number of layers
sec.p:
Computation presented in Tables 2 and 3 have been realized with a constant number of layers, for all the preforms studied, we propose in this part to study the influence of the number of layers for stiffer, filler and biases set of tows on the geometrical parameters. For the 2-A1-B3-C3 preform (μf = 800 Tex, μb = 198 Tex and λs = 3) selected, Table 6 reports the results obtained from our geometrical model. These results follow the same conclusions that those presented with the same number of layers concerning first the very weak effect of the thickness consideration (crowned–uncrowned) on the rate of fiber between each group (stiffer, filler and bias) and second concerning the higher global fiber volume fraction obtained with a method based on the volume (FVFvolume) compared to the method based on the weight (FVFweight). With the augmentation of the number of layers (Table 6), the total thickness of the preform, calculated by the uncrowned configuration, also changes. When the number of layers increase we can notice a consequent diminution (between −5% and −10.2%) on the difference to compute the thickness calculated by the uncrowned configuration to that calculated by the crowned configuration. In function of the binder tows dimension, this reduction has an influence on the fiber volume fraction when computed in the uncrowned configuration to that computed in the crowned configuration (augmentation between +5.3% and +11.3%), and this difference could be expressed by the following equations (18)Dif.FVFHuc to FVFHc=FVFHuc-FVFHcFVFHc*100 (19)Dif.FVFHuc to FVFHc=2Vfiberuchb-SbLyHucHuc(SbLy+Vfiberuc)*100 Table 6.

Associated with the values considered in Table 6, in equation (19) the parameters hb, Sb and Ly remain constant and only Huc and Vfiberuc are function of the number of the layer. Figure 10 represents this difference (equation (18)) in function of the total number of layers in preforms, with the variation of the preform thickness in the uncrowned configuration. This evolution can be superposed by equation (19), expressed as a model. This result shows that when the number of layer reaches 20 the difference between the two methods to compute the thickness is weak. Figure 10.
Difference in the fiber volume fraction value computed in the uncrowned configuration to that computed in the crowned configuration in function of the total number of layer in preform and of the total thickness of preform in the uncrowned configuration.

sec.title: Comparisons between multiaxial 3D woven preform and other 3D preform configurations
sec.p:
In this section, the previous model has been used to compute the geometrical properties of an equivalent laminate and one 3D orthogonal woven preform, in fact the model has been used to compare to the geometrical properties of a multiaxial 3D woven preform. The optimized architecture selected previously, denoted 2-A1-B3-C3 has been chosen, with its two configurations, crowned and uncrowned. Geometrical parameters are reported in Table 7. Due to the weak proportion of binder tows considered in this example the geometrical properties of the 3D multiaxial woven preform remains near to the equivalent laminate. It could also be deduced that the introduction of the bias tows leads to the reduction of the overall fiber volume fraction compared to an equivalent 3D orthogonal (between 8.9% and 16% depending on the configuration used to calculate the thickness, crowned or uncrowned configuration). The advantages of the introduction of bias tows compared to 3D orthogonal woven preform can be shown, with the in-plane shear modulus computed by homogenization technique leads at the scale of unit cell. For these mechanical computations conducted by finite element a geometrical model, like those described in this article, is necessary to describe the geometry and then for meshing the part. Table 7.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: An optimization method has been associated with a geometrical model, in fact to compute the dimension of tow cross section for the definition of the dry multiaxial 3D woven preform. This optimization loop takes into account the specific manufacturing and the weaving parameters and their influence on the geometrical properties of the preform. The two methods described in the Ansar et al.13 and Buchanan et al.17 to calculate the overall volume fraction have been applied and their influence have been analyzed. The geometrical model allowed to select an optimized configuration, in terms of fiber volume fraction for multiaxial 3D woven preform. With this numerical model the influence of the choice of specific shapes for cross section and also variations due to the weaving, as the orientation of the binder tows has been studied. Based on the works presented by Rao et al.14 the influence of two types of configuration denoted by ‘crowned and uncrowned’ has been analyzed, in this study, through the number of layers. This aspect was not described in the literature, and it has been shown that the difference due to these configurations could be negligible when the number of layers approaches 20. With this numerical model, comparisons, based on geometrical properties, have been conducted between several architectures of 3D preform. In future works, this geometrical model will be associated with a mechanical model, by finite element, in fact to also estimate mechanical properties of these multiaxial 3D woven preforms. Otherwise, a specific loom able to produce these architectures is in development. With this machine, we could evaluate the real properties of sample and compare with those computed by these models.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
